articles.title: Does Failing a PED Test Disqualify Jon Jones From GOAT Status?
articles.description: Coach Javier Mendez recently stated that Jon Jones should not be included in the GOAT discussion because of a failed PED test. That argument sounds reasonable ‚Äî but it doesn‚Äôt settle the issue. The real question isn‚Äôt whether Jon Jones was the cleanest athlete of all time. It‚Äôs whether he was the greatest fighter of all time ‚Äî and those are not the same conversation. Standards change. Rules evolve. Substances banned today may be permitted tomorrow, just as many things once allowed are now prohibited. Evaluating greatness across eras quickly becomes complicated. If given a choice ‚Äî one fighter‚Äôs complete skill set, passed down to the next generation ‚Äî most would choose Jon Jones. Not because of paperwork or testing history, but because of skill, adaptability, and dominance inside the cage. This discussion also raises broader questions: How do failed tests factor into legacy? Who decides when an asterisk applies? How should fighters from different eras be compared? Where do legends like Fedor Emelianenko and Khabib Nurmagomedov fit into the conversation? The conclusion is clear: Jon Jones may not be the cleanest fighter of all time ‚Äî but failing a PED test does not disqualify him from being the greatest fighter of all time. CHAPTER BREAKDOWNS 0:00 ‚Äî Javier Mendes‚Äô Claim Why failing a PED test is being used to exclude Jon Jones from the GOAT discussion. 0:39 ‚Äî Clean vs Greatest Why ‚Äúcleanest fighter‚Äù and ‚Äúgreatest fighter‚Äù are two completely different conversations. 1:05 ‚Äî Rules Change Over Time How banned substances, testing standards, and enforcement shift across eras. 1:38 ‚Äî The Skill Test Thought Experiment If you could pass one fighter‚Äôs skills to the next generation, who would you choose? 2:27 ‚Äî Does a Failed Test Require an Asterisk? Who decides legacy disqualification ‚Äî fans, commissions, or history? 3:00 ‚Äî Where Does Fedor Fit? Why fighters without UFC runs are often discounted ‚Äî fairly or unfairly. 3:34 ‚Äî Comparing Eras Is Inherently Flawed Why dominance in one era doesn‚Äôt translate cleanly to another. 4:13 ‚Äî Fighters Who Used PEDs but Never Failed Why the discussion becomes a slippery slope when enforcement is inconsistent. 4:56 ‚Äî Cleanest Fighter vs Greatest Fighter Why Jon Jones clearly fails one category but remains eligible for the other. 5:18 ‚Äî GOAT vs ‚ÄúGreatest of His Time‚Äù Why this framing may be the most honest way to evaluate legacy. 5:59 ‚Äî Final Verdict Why failing a PED test does not disqualify Jon Jones from GOAT consideration. articles.title: Is the White House Fight Dead? #ufc
articles.description: Did Jon Jones just quietly walk away from the biggest fight of his career? Chael Sonnen reacts to a surprising interview where Jones revealed something we don‚Äôt normally hear from champions ‚Äî severe arthritis in his hip. Not soreness. Not wear and tear. Severe arthritis. And for the first time in a long time, Jon wasn‚Äôt talking about fights, belts, or comebacks. He was talking about life after fighting. No mention of a White House supercard. No mention of competing. No big callouts. Instead, Jones talked about protecting what he has left physically and spending time playing with his son. That‚Äôs not the language of a guy gearing up for Alex Pereira or any mega-event. Then Pereira adds fuel to the fire, saying flat-out he won‚Äôt be fighting Jon Jones at the White House. Put it together, and Chael connects the dots: this might not be negotiation tactics. This might be reality. Jones may have just removed himself from contention entirely. If the dream superfight was ever going to happen‚Ä¶ this could be the moment it died. articles.title: Ilia‚Äôs Next Fight Isn‚Äôt Who You Think #ufc
articles.description: The champ is back ‚Äî and no, Chael Sonnen isn‚Äôt talking about himself. He‚Äôs talking about Ilia Topuria. Topuria returning means one thing: massive fights. And on paper, the biggest fight you can possibly make in the sport right now is simple ‚Äî Ilia Topuria vs. Islam Makhachev. Champion vs. champion. Star vs. star. It sells itself. But Chael says pump the brakes. The UFC likely isn‚Äôt booking that unless Ilia gives up his belt or fully commits to lightweight. That‚Äôs a big sacrifice ‚Äî and historically, the company doesn‚Äôt force those moves lightly. Which means the fight we think we‚Äôre getting‚Ä¶ probably isn‚Äôt next. So what is? Enter Justin Gaethje. Chael argues we‚Äôve disrespected Gaethje long enough. This isn‚Äôt just some action fighter ‚Äî this is a true competitor. Former UFC champion Frankie Edgar floated an idea that instantly got the MMA world talking ‚Äî not calling for retirement, but suggesting that Alexander Volkanovski consider leaving the sport on his own terms. Frankie‚Äôs point wasn‚Äôt disrespectful. It was reflective. Nobody ever truly gets to go out on top in this game. Fighters stay too long. They lose a step. The ending writes itself. On the surface, it looks like a budget decision. In reality, it‚Äôs a warning sign. Chael Sonnen explains why this move has far bigger implications than one school or one sport. The NIL era was created to fix a real problem‚Äîthe NCAA keeping massive revenues while athletes received nothing. That imbalance needed correction. But the current system has created a new one. Money is now being funneled almost entirely into football and men‚Äôs basketball. Olympic sports‚Äîthe very programs that develop discipline, sacrifice, and long-term excellence‚Äîare being cut to make room. Wrestling is just one of the first casualties. Sonnen lays out a perspective rarely discussed: Olympic sports matter at a national level. Countries take Olympic performance seriously because it reflects something deeper‚Äîdiscipline, resilience, and the ability of young people to train, sacrifice, follow instruction, and succeed under pressure. That same age group, those same qualities, are what nations quietly measure through Olympic competition. And here‚Äôs the part many people miss: Olympic athletes do not come from training centers. They come from universities. The NCAA system feeds freestyle and Greco-Roman wrestling, track and field, gymnastics, and other Olympic disciplines. When college programs disappear, the pipeline collapses. This isn‚Äôt nostalgia. It‚Äôs infrastructure. Cal Baptist‚Äôs decision highlights a growing trend. Olympic sports are being stripped away not because they failed‚Äîbut because the system around them changed. If this continues, the damage won‚Äôt show up immediately. It will show up years later, when the pipeline is gone and can‚Äôt be rebuilt. #Wrestling #NIL #NCAA #OlympicSports #CollegeWrestling #ChaelSonnen #CombatSports #USAOlympics Bad Guy Inc merch now available at https://BadGuyInc.com Click here to subscribe: https://bit.ly/3FrHIPK Follow me on IG: https://bit.ly/3HY7BIE Follow me on Twitter: https://bit.ly/3tvY5J7 Follow me on Threads https://www.threads.com/@sonnench
